Atlassian has found 4 new RCE vulnerabilities in its products.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 524/66 (IT) Friday, December 8, 2023. Atlassian, an Australian software company, has disclosed 4 vulnerabilities that allow Remote Code Execution (RCE). Security patches have been released to address these Remote Code Execution (RCE) vulnerabilities. The details of the vulnerabilities are as follows:

– CVE-2022-1471 (CVSS score: 9.8) is an RCE vulnerability in the SnakeYAML library that affects several products. Many Atlassian data center and server products use the SnakeYAML library for Java, which is vulnerable to deserialization that can lead to RCE (Remote Code Execution).
– CVE-2023-22522 (CVSS score: 9.0) is an RCE vulnerability in Confluence Data Center and Confluence Server.
– CVE-2023-22523 (CVSS score: 9.8) If exploited, this vulnerability allows attackers to perform RCE (Remote Code Execution) by gaining privileges on the machine where the Assets Discovery agent is installed.
– CVE-2023-22524 (CVSS score: 9.6) All versions of the Atlassian Companion app for MacOS, except version 2.0.0, are affected by the Remote Code Execution (RCE) vulnerability CVE-2023-22524. This allows attackers to use WebSockets to bypass the Atlassian Companion and MacOS Gatekeeper block lists to allow code execution.

It is not clear whether all of these vulnerabilities have been exploited in the wild.

[TLP:GREEN] Alert - Additional Investigation Report on Attacks in the BangkokShell Campaign

The TTC-CERT has investigated several suspicious files received from a security agency in Thailand and found that all files are related to the BangkokShell cyber attack campaign.  TTC-CERT previously published information about this campaign in June 2023 in a report titled "Alert - Report on the Discovery of the BangkokShell Campaign Specifically Targeting Organizations in Thailand" (https://drive.google.com/file/d/14OdsocsRVK6osG3TLxyGSB0fJZaaS2fK/view).  The results of this analysis indicate that the malware files were compiled before the malware files found in the report "Alert - Report on the Discovery of the BangkokShell Campaign Specifically Targeting Organizations in Thailand." However, there are differences in Tactics, Techniques, and Procedures (TTPs), which indicate that the attackers' operations have been ongoing and that they are continuously improving and developing their malware and seeking tools to achieve their objectives. This report will describe the overall functionality of the malware files found, analyze the changes that have occurred, and understand the reasons behind these changes.

TTC-CERT has prepared this alert report and identified "Indicators of Compromise (IOCs)" to inform organizations and the general public. This information can be used to assess risks and take appropriate actions to secure information systems and networks.  If your organization is connected to the TTC-CERT MISP system, the Indicators of Compromise (IOCs) from this report will be sent to your MISP instance.

"Hadooken," a new Linux malware, targets Oracle WebLogic servers.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 326/67 (IT) Tuesday, September 17, 2024. Researchers from Aqua Security discovered new malware called "Hadooken," which attacks WebLogic servers.  The malware's name comes from an attack move in the game Street Fighter.  Hadooken's capabilities include installing cryptocurrency mining software (cryptominer) and deploying Tsunami malware, which can be used for later system breaches.  This attack targets WebLogic servers, developed by Oracle and often used in large organizations. Attackers gain access to the servers through weak passwords. They then use shell scripts and Python to download and install the malware on the server, while also attempting to hide traces of the attack. Researchers found that the Hadooken malware was downloaded from two IP addresses: 89.185.85.102 (still active), registered in Germany, and 185.174.136.204 (no longer active), registered in Russia.  The still-active IP has been linked to the TeamTNT and Gang 8220 groups. However, researchers do not yet have enough evidence to confirm the source of this attack.  Searching for additional information through Shodan revealed more than 230,000 WebLogic servers connected to the internet. Although most are well-protected, some may be vulnerable to attack.  Researchers recommend that administrators monitor and update their software to prevent future attacks.  https://www.thaicert.or.th/2024/09/17/hadooken-%e0%b8%a1%e0%b8%b1%e0%b8%a5%e0%b9%81%e0%b8%a7%e0%b8%a3%e0%b9%8c-linux-%e0%b8%95%e0%b8%b1%e0%b8%a7%e0%b9%83%e0%b8%ab%e0%b8%a1%e0%b9%88-%e0%b8%81%e0%b8%b3%e0%b8%ab%e0%b8%99%e0%b8%94/

Discussing the impact of cybersecurity in DSM and EU growth
The impact of cybersecurity in the Digital Single Market (DSM) and an EU perspective on economic growth was presented by  Head of Stakeholder Relations and Administration, Dr Paulo Empadinhas, during the 2016 European Security Conference organised by the ISEG University of Lisbon on the 15th -17th June 2016.

Paulo Empadinhas in his keynote speech gave an overview of the challenges of the DSM, highlighting there are still gaps to be addressed and a more joint-up approach is required to step up supply of more secure solutions by EU industry, and stimulate take-up by enterprises, public authorities, and citizens.
“We witness a lack of education regarding security: from school, academia and in private companies. Education should bring a stronger awareness about the need for security in products, both from the supplier side and the customer. Similarly, a lot of EU companies invest in IoT as a business enabler, however they don’t invest in security. In addition, security as we know it does not apply to the IoT environment, hence new frameworks are required to analyse risks” said Paulo Empadinhas.
 through its work, supports EU Member States in implementing the requirements of the NIS Directive, and initiatives such as the eIDAS, GDPR, which stimulate trust across different stakeholders and support industry policy in cybersecurity. Furthermore,  encourages the use of standardisation - a main pillar in creating the EU single market – which helps support market-based competition, removes market barriers and helps ensure interoperability.
The conference is the European extension of the Annual Security Conference taking place in Las Vegas (USA) for over a decade gathering participants from academia, government and industry to look into ‘the future of cybersecurity’.
For more @EuropeanSeC2015  #iseg https://www.enisa.europa.eu/news/enisa-news/discussing-the-impact-of-cybersecurity-in-dsm-and-eu-growth

North Korean hackers are using a new version of the BeaverTail malware to target macOS users.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 258/67 (IT) Friday, July 19, 2024. Cybersecurity researcher Patrick Wardle has revealed the latest campaign by North Korean-backed hackers, known for scamming victims with fake job postings. This time, they're using a new version of the BeaverTail malware to trick macOS users into downloading a malicious version of Microtalk, a video call service.  Wardle explains in his report that the attackers lure victims into downloading a Microtalk update file infected with BeaverTail malware by asking them to participate in a job interview. "Even though the fake website states 'you can start your next video chat with a single click, without downloading anything,' some users may not read all the details," Wardle said.  In addition to stealing data from victims' devices, BeaverTail malware can also load additional malware onto the system, including InvisibleFerret.  The report adds that North Korean hackers are skilled at targeting macOS users with social engineering attacks.  The campaign demonstrates the development of new techniques and methods by North Korean hackers to deceive and attack users, especially in the context of job searches and interviews.  https://www.thaicert.or.th/2024/07/19/%e0%b9%81%e0%b8%ae%e0%b8%81%e0%b9%80%e0%b8%81%e0%b8%ad%e0%b8%a3%e0%b9%8c%e0%b8%88%e0%b8%b2%e0%b8%81%e0%b9%80%e0%b8%81%e0%b8%b2%e0%b8%ab%e0%b8%a5%e0%b8%b5%e0%b9%80%e0%b8%ab%e0%b8%99%e0%b8%b7%e0%b8%ad/

On Monday, Apple released iOS and iPadOS with security patches to address several serious vulnerabilities that exposed mobile users to malicious attacks from malicious hackers.  The latest iOS 17.2 and iPadOS 17.2 fix at least 11 documented security vulnerabilities, the most serious of which is a memory corruption issue in ImageIO that could lead to arbitrary code execution when processing certain images. The iOS 17.2 release also addresses code execution vulnerabilities in the WebKit rendering engine and memory security issues that allowed applications to break out of the device's sandbox. The company also fixed a privacy issue in Accounts, an information disclosure issue in AVEVideoEncoder, an extension suite that allowed access to sensitive user data, and a Siri flaw that allowed attackers with physical access using voice bots to access sensitive user information.  https://www.thaicert.or.th/2023/12/13/apple-%e0%b9%80%e0%b8%9b%e0%b8%b4%e0%b8%94%e0%b8%95%e0%b8%b1%e0%b8%a7-ios-17-2-%e0%b8%9e%e0%b8%a3%e0%b9%89%e0%b8%ad%e0%b8%a1%e0%b9%81%e0%b8%9e%e0%b8%95%e0%b8%8a%e0%b9%8c%e0%b8%84%e0%b8%a7%e0%b8%b2/

Samsung Experiences Data Breach

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 496/66 (IT) Friday, November 17, 2023 Samsung Electronics experienced a data breach that exposed customer personal information without authorization.  The data breach was discovered on November 13, 2023, and affects customers who purchased products from the Samsung UK online store between July 1, 2019, and June 30, 2020.  Attackers exploited a vulnerability in an application, the name of which the company did not specify. The company informed customers that affected information may include name, phone number, address, and email address, stating that financial information was not affected.  A Samsung spokesperson told BleepingComputer that the security breach is limited to the United Kingdom and affects only e-store customers. Notification - Analysis report on the discovery of Infostealer specifically targeting Thai users.

The Telecommunications Computer Emergency Response Team Coordination Center (TTC-CERT) has been closely monitoring and tracking malware used in attacks against Thai citizens. During routine open-source intelligence (OSINT) research on the internet, the TTC-CERT discovered the website hxxps://sites.google.com/view/documentfb being used to distribute files containing Infostealer malware.  The website is written in Thai and entices users to download files from links within the site. The TTC-CERT believes the attackers created this website specifically to target Thai users.

The Infostealer malware used in this attack is capable of stealing data from web browsers, such as passwords, cookies, and browsing history. It can also steal sessions from various applications, including Discord, Telegram, Instagram, Twitter, Reddit, and Tiktok.  Furthermore, the malware can steal information related to the victim's crypto wallet and collect basic information about the target computer, such as computer name, operating system version, and RAM size.  This data is then exfiltrated via Discord Webhook and the attacker's Command and Control (C2) server. Details of the overall infection chain are illustrated in Figure 1.

LiteSpeed Cache plugin vulnerability on WordPress could allow website takeover. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 352/67 (IT) Monday, October 7, 2024.  A recent discovery reveals a high-severity vulnerability in the LiteSpeed Cache plugin on WordPress, which could allow attackers to execute arbitrary JavaScript code. This vulnerability is identified as CVE-2024-47374 and has a CVSS severity score of 7.2, affecting versions up to 6.5.0.2 of the plugin with over 6 million installations. The vulnerability stems from a Cross-site Scripting (XSS) issue that allows attackers to steal sensitive information or escalate privileges on WordPress websites by performing a single HTTP request. If certain settings are enabled, such as “CSS Combine” and “Generate UCSS,” this vulnerability could allow attackers to take control of the entire website.  LiteSpeed Cache is a popular plugin used in WordPress for website acceleration and is often used with popular plugins like WooCommerce and Yoast SEO, making it highly vulnerable to attacks. A fix for this vulnerability was released in version 6.5.1 on September 25, 2024. Website administrators should update immediately to prevent attacks from malicious actors. In addition, the developers also fixed another vulnerability identified as CVE-2024-44000, which allowed attackers to access cookie information and escalate privileges to administrator level.  This vulnerability was fixed in version 6.5.0.1 of the plugin.  https://www.thaicert.or.th/2024/10/07/%e0%b8%8a%e0%b9%88%e0%b8%ad%e0%b8%87%e0%b9%82%e0%b8%ab%e0%b8%a7%e0%b9%88%e0%b8%82%e0%b8%ad%e0%b8%87%e0%b8%9b%e0%b8%a5%e0%b8%b1%e0%b9%8a%e0%b8%81%e0%b8%ad%e0%b8%b4%e0%b8%99-litespeed-cache-%e0%b8%9a/

new good practice guide for CERTs - Issuing alerts, warnings and announcements
 has launched today (25th November) a new good practice guide that complements the existing set of  guides for supporting Computer Emergency Response Teams (CERTs, also known as CSIRTs). The new guide describes good practices and provides practical information and guidelines for the process of preparing and issuing alerts, warnings and announcements to a CERT’s constituency.

The main focus area of the 's guide on alerts, warnings and announcements is the process of informing the CERTs and their constituencies about threats and ways to contain them – a core service carried out by most CERTs – which involves having an identified and reliable set of information sources and a well-structured process of assessing and processing the incoming information, enabling the CERT to get the right information at the right places in the most timely fashion.
Goal
This good practice guide aims to:
inform about the current best practices in preparing and issuing alerts, warnings and announcements for the CERT’s constituency,
suggest ways in which alerting processes can be improved, not only inside an organisation but also in cooperation with others, especially the CERT community and IT security vendors
For the full report:
Alerts-Warnings-Announcements https://www.enisa.europa.eu/news/enisa-news/enisa-new-good-practice-guide-for-certs-issuing-alerts-warnings-and-announcements

Android's September 2023 security updates include patches for 32 vulnerabilities, including one that has been exploited in attacks. Google has been aware of several Android zero-day vulnerabilities in recent years, and many of them have been exploited by groups selling commercial spyware.  Five additional high-severity vulnerabilities were addressed in the Framework, with three leading to privilege escalation and two being information disclosure flaws. Google also announced that two other issues were fixed in Project Mainline components with updates delivered via Google Play. These updates target critical Android components without requiring devices to reboot. The second part of this month's Android security updates will arrive on devices as the 2023-09-05 security patch level, with fixes for 12 more vulnerabilities in Qualcomm components.  The annual security patch level addresses all vulnerabilities in this month's security updates, and issues addressed with prior patch levels. Attackers can obtain IP ADDRESSes by sending links via the mobile SKYPE application.
Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 393/66 (IT) Wednesday, August 30, 2023.  Security researcher Yossi found that it is possible to discover the IP ADDRESS of a target by sending a link through the mobile Skype application. The researcher pointed out that the attack method only requires the target to open the message. This attack method can only be performed on the mobile Skype app. Obtaining the target's IP ADDRESS allows malicious actors to locate their physical location or residence, posing a privacy risk.  This attack could pose a serious risk to activists, political dissidents, journalists, or those targeted by cybercriminals, and many others. According to a report by 404 Media, Yossi reported the issue to Microsoft earlier this month, but the company seemed to initially overlook the problem and did not indicate plans to fix the flaw. However, after 404 Media contacted Microsoft for information, the company announced plans to address the issue in the next application update. 404 Media only revealed that the issue can be exploited by manipulating certain parameters related to the link, but has not disclosed details of the attack since the vulnerability has not yet been patched.  https://www.thaicert.or.th/2023/08/30/%e0%b8%9c%e0%b8%b9%e0%b9%89%e0%b9%82%e0%b8%88%e0%b8%a1%e0%b8%95%e0%b8%b5%e0%b8%aa%e0%b8%b2%e0%b8%a1%e0%b8%b2%e0%b8%a3%e0%b8%96%e0%b8%ab%e0%b8%b2-ip-address-%e0%b9%84%e0%b8%94%e0%b9%89%e0%b9%82/

Happy Europe Day, from !
 wishes everyone in the EU and everywhere a Happy Europe Day!

Europe Day (9 May) celebrates peace and unity in Europe. The date marks the anniversary of the historical '
Schuman declaration
'. At a speech in Paris in 1950, the French foreign minister, Robert Schuman, set out his idea for a new form of political cooperation in Europe, which would make war between Europe’s nations unthinkable.
His vision was to create a European institution that would pool and manage coal and steel production. A treaty creating such a body was signed just under a year later. Schuman’s proposal is considered to be the beginning of what is now the European Union.
To find out more about the European Union and its work for citizens, see:

Exploitation of Apache HTTP Server vulnerabilities originating from a Thai university network.

TTC-CERT has detected exploitation attempts targeting Apache HTTP Server vulnerabilities (CVE-2021-42013 and CVE-2021-41773) originating from the network of a Thai university (202.28.2501.1118 and 202.28.250[.1122) between October 19, 2021, 17:03:22 (UTC) and October 23, 2021, 05:06:21 (UTC).  There is credible evidence suggesting the attackers aimed to exploit these vulnerabilities to install cryptocurrency mining software.

TTC-CERT has compiled a list of Indicators of Compromise (IOCs) and is regularly updating information related to these exploits.  This information is available to readers and members for organizational use.  If your organization is connected to TTC-CERT's MISP (Malware Information Sharing Platform), this data will be automatically sent to your organization's MISP instance.

Vulnerabilities CVE-2021-42013 and CVE-2021-41773:  Around October 4-7, 2021, the Apache Software Foundation released a security advisory regarding CVE-2021-42013 and CVE-2021-41773. These are Path Traversal vulnerabilities that could allow unauthenticated remote code execution on unpatched, affected versions of Apache HTTP Server.

Following the security advisory, a significant increase in scans targeting these vulnerabilities was observed across the internet.  TTC-CERT has collected data on these scans and exploitation attempts to study attacker behavior. This article analyzes the attacker's payload, the attack pattern, and summarizes the Indicators of Compromise (IOCs) to aid organizations in detection and prevention.

Application Layer Protocol: DNS is techniques, 

Adversaries may communicate using the Domain Name System (DNS) application layer protocol to avoid detection/network filtering by blending in with existing traffic. Commands to the remote system, and often the results of those commands, will be embedded within the protocol traffic between the client and server. 
The DNS protocol serves an administrative function in computer networking and thus may be very common in environments. DNS traffic may also be allowed even before network authentication is completed. DNS packets contain many fields and headers in which data can be concealed. Often known as DNS tunneling, adversaries may abuse DNS to communicate with systems under their control within a victim network while also mimicking normal, expected traffic.

Zimbra RCE Vulnerability at High Risk of Attack, Users Must Update Immediately

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 348/67 (IT) Thursday, October 3, 2024.  A Remote Code Execution (RCE) vulnerability on Zimbra servers has recently been disclosed. This vulnerability, CVE-2024-45519, allows attackers to execute arbitrary commands and immediately take control of vulnerable systems. Zimbra has released an update to address this issue but has not yet disclosed in-depth details about the flaw.

Researchers from Proofpoint have observed attacks targeting this vulnerability since September 28th. Attackers sent spoofed emails from Gmail with base64-encoded malicious code via the CC field to execute shell commands on vulnerable servers. This allowed attackers to install web shells, enabling remote access and control of the server. Researchers from HarfangLab indicated that the source of these malicious emails originated from a server in Bulgaria and urged administrators to apply the patch as soon as possible to prevent attacks.  Proofpoint reports that the volume of attacks has not decreased since they began and appears to be opportunistic, not specifically targeting any particular organization.

Researchers also warn that patching this vulnerability is critical, as Zimbra is widely used in both corporate and government sectors worldwide, making it a prime target for attackers seeking to steal sensitive data.  https://www.thaicert.or.th/2024/10/03/%e0%b8%8a%e0%b9%88%e0%b8%ad%e0%b8%87%e0%b9%82%e0%b8%ab%e0%b8%a7%e0%b9%88-zimbra-rce-%e0%b9%80%e0%b8%aa%e0%b8%b5%e0%b9%88%e0%b8%a2%e0%b8%87%e0%b8%96%e0%b8%b9%e0%b8%81%e0%b9%82%e0%b8%88%e0%b8%a1/

Acquire Infrastructure: Malvertising is techniques, 

Adversaries may purchase online advertisements that can be abused to distribute malware to victims. Ads can be purchased to plant as well as favorably position artifacts in specific locations  online, such as prominently placed within search engine results. These ads may make it more difficult for users to distinguish between actual search results and advertisements.
 Purchased ads may also target specific audiences using the advertising network’s capabilities, potentially further taking advantage of the trust inherently given to search engines and popular websites. 
Adversaries may purchase ads and other resources to help distribute artifacts containing malicious code to victims. Purchased ads may attempt to impersonate or spoof well-known brands. For example, these spoofed ads may trick victims into clicking the ad which could then send them to a malicious domain that may be a clone of official websites containing trojanized versions of the advertised software.
 Adversary’s efforts to create malicious domains and purchase advertisements may also be automated at scale to better resist cleanup efforts.
 
Malvertising may be used to support 
 and 
, potentially requiring limited interaction from the user if the ad contains code/exploits that infect the target system's web browser.
Adversaries may also employ several techniques to evade detection by the advertising network. For example, adversaries may dynamically route ad clicks to send automated crawler/policy enforcer traffic to benign sites while validating potential targets then sending victims referred from real ad clicks to malicious pages. This infection vector may therefore remain hidden from the ad network as well as any visitor not reaching the malicious sites with a valid identifier from clicking on the advertisement.
 Other tricks, such as intentional typos to avoid brand reputation monitoring, may also be used to evade automated detection.

Exposure of Sensitive Information Through Sent Data # Description : 


# Extend Description : 


# Migration : 
Potential Mitigations
Phase: Requirements
Specify which data in the software should be regarded as sensitive. Consider which types of users should have access to which types of data.
Phase: Implementation
Ensure that any possibly sensitive data specified in the requirements is verified with designers to ensure that it is either a calculated risk or mitigated elsewhere. Any information that is not necessary to the functionality should be removed in order to lower both the overhead and the possibility of security sensitive data being sent.
Phase: System Configuration
Setup default error messages so that unexpected errors do not disclose sensitive information.
Phase: Architecture and Design
Strategy: Separation of Privilege
Compartmentalize the system to have "safe" areas where trust boundaries can be unambiguously drawn. Do not allow sensitive data to go outside of the trust boundary and always be careful when interfacing with a compartment outside of the safe area.
Ensure that appropriate compartmentalization is built into the system design, and the compartmentalization allows for and reinforces privilege separation functionality. Architects and designers should rely on the principle of least privilege to decide the appropriate time to use privileges and the time to drop privileges.
 https://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/201.html

Spain's Globalcaja bank confirms Play ransomware attack.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 289/66 (IT) Tuesday, June 6, 2023. Globalcaja bank is a financial institution in the autonomous community of Castilla-La Mancha, with more than 300 branches throughout Spain, serving more than half a million customers. Globalcaja has fallen victim to a ransomware attack by the group called Play, which has affected operations in several of the bank's offices. The Play ransomware group has added the bank to its list of victims on its data leak site on Tor, claiming to have stolen private and confidential information, customer and employee documents, passports, contracts, and more.  The group will publish the stolen data on June 11, 2023, if the bank doesn't pay the ransom.  The bank confirmed the incident in a press release. The bank attempted to downplay the attack, stating that it did not affect the transactions of the business or customers. However, as part of the incident response, some operations have been temporarily limited and the bank is investigating the incident. The Play ransomware group launched its first attack in July 2022, with victims including the city of Oakland and cloud provider Rackspace. Later, in March, the Play ransomware group attacked the Dutch maritime logistics company Royal Dirkzwager.  https://www.thaicert.or.th/2023/06/06/%e0%b8%98%e0%b8%99%e0%b8%b2%e0%b8%84%e0%b8%b2%e0%b8%a3-globalcaja-%e0%b8%82%e0%b8%ad%e0%b8%87%e0%b8%aa%e0%b9%80%e0%b8%9b%e0%b8%99-%e0%b8%a2%e0%b8%b7%e0%b8%99%e0%b8%a2%e0%b8%b1%e0%b8%99%e0%b8%96/

Process Injection: VDSO Hijacking is techniques, 

Adversaries may inject malicious code into processes via VDSO hijacking in order to evade process-based defenses as well as possibly elevate privileges. Virtual dynamic shared object (vdso) hijacking is a method of executing arbitrary code in the address space of a separate live process. 
VDSO hijacking involves redirecting calls to dynamically linked shared libraries. Memory protections may prevent writing executable code to a process via 
. However, an adversary may hijack the syscall interface code stubs mapped into a process from the vdso shared object to execute syscalls to open and map a malicious shared object. This code can then be invoked by redirecting the execution flow of the process via patched memory address references stored in a process' global offset table (which store absolute addresses of mapped library functions).
Running code in the context of another process may allow access to the process's memory, system/network resources, and possibly elevated privileges. Execution via VDSO hijacking may also evade detection from security products since the execution is masked under a legitimate process.  
 https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1055/014/

Adversary-in-the-Middle: DHCP Spoofing is techniques, 

Adversaries may redirect network traffic to adversary-owned systems by spoofing Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP) traffic and acting as a malicious DHCP server on the victim network. By achieving the adversary-in-the-middle (AiTM) position, adversaries may collect network communications, including passed credentials, especially those sent over insecure, unencrypted protocols. This may also enable follow-on behaviors such as 
 or 
.
DHCP is based on a client-server model and has two functionalities: a protocol for providing network configuration settings from a DHCP server to a client and a mechanism for allocating network addresses to clients.
 The typical server-client interaction is as follows: 
Adversaries may spoof as a rogue DHCP server on the victim network, from which legitimate hosts may receive malicious network configurations. For example, malware can act as a DHCP server and provide adversary-owned DNS servers to the victimized computers.
 Through the malicious network configurations, an adversary may achieve the AiTM position, route client traffic through adversary-controlled systems, and collect information from the client network.
DHCPv6 clients can receive network configuration information without being assigned an IP address by sending a 
 message to the 
 multicast address.
 Adversaries may use their rogue DHCP server to respond to this request message with malicious network configurations.
Rather than establishing an AiTM position, adversaries may also abuse DHCP spoofing to perform a DHCP exhaustion attack (i.e, 
) by generating many broadcast DISCOVER messages to exhaust a network’s DHCP allocation pool.

Over 39,000 websites infected with new malware in ‘Sign1’ campaign

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 117/67 (IT) Tuesday, March 26, 2024. Website security company Sucuri warns that more than 39,000 websites are infected with a new family of malware that redirects website visitors to fraudulent domains and unwanted advertisements. The name Sign1 comes from the discovery of JavaScript malware in WordPress custom HTML widgets or within the Simple Custom CSS and JS WordPress plugin that attackers added to compromised websites. Using this method, hackers spread malware to websites without placing malicious code in server files, allowing the malware to go unnoticed for long periods, as it is common for security providers to scan website files for malware rather than checking databases. The injected code is responsible for changing the URL to be executed in the victim's browser every 10 minutes, but only if the visitor comes from major websites such as Facebook, Google, Instagram, and Yahoo. In the past six months, Sucuri has identified more than 39,000 websites infected with various forms of this malware, and recently more than 2,500 websites have been infected in the past two months. Therefore, maintaining security, system administration, and website monitoring should be a top priority for website owners.  https://www.thaicert.or.th/2024/03/26/%e0%b9%80%e0%b8%a7%e0%b9%87%e0%b8%9a%e0%b9%84%e0%b8%8b%e0%b8%95%e0%b9%8c%e0%b8%81%e0%b8%a7%e0%b9%88%e0%b8%b2-39000-%e0%b9%81%e0%b8%ab%e0%b9%88%e0%b8%87-%e0%b8%95%e0%b8%b4%e0%b8%94%e0%b8%a1%e0%b8%b1/

Modernisation & reform proposal for Data Protection
On 25 January 2012, the European Commission proposed a comprehensive reform of the EU's 1995 data protection rules to strengthen online privacy rights and boost Europe's digital economy.

The Commission's proposals update and modernise the principles enshrined in the 1995 Data Protection Directive to bring them into the digital age. They include a proposal for a Regulation setting out a general EU framework for data protection, and a proposal for a Directive on protecting personal data processed for the purposes of prevention, detection, investigation or prosecution of criminal offences and related judicial activities.

ThyssenKrupp, a steel giant, confirms a cyberattack on its automotive division.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 80/67 (IT) Wednesday, February 28, 2024. ThyssenKrupp confirmed a systems breach attack on its automotive division last week, forcing IT systems to shut down to respond to the threat. ThyssenKrupp is one of the world's largest steel producers, with more than 100,000 employees and annual revenue of more than $44.4 billion (2022). A company spokesperson confirmed that the attack only affected the Thyssenkrupp Automotive Body Solutions business unit. The Automotive Body Solutions IT security team worked with the ThyssenKrupp Group IT security team to contain the threat. Therefore, various security measures were implemented, and some system applications were temporarily shut down. ThyssenKrupp further clarified that none of the other units were affected by the cyberattack. BleepingComputer contacted ThyssenKrupp to inquire about the reported outage. The company confirmed that production systems were shut down but clarified that customers were not affected. Currently, no ransomware group or threat actor has claimed responsibility for the attack on ThyssenKrupp. Thus the type of breach remains unknown.  https://www.thaicert.or.th/2024/02/28/%e0%b8%9a%e0%b8%a3%e0%b8%b4%e0%b8%a9%e0%b8%b1%e0%b8%97-thyssenkrupp-%e0%b8%94%e0%b9%89%e0%b8%b2%e0%b8%99%e0%b9%80%e0%b8%ab%e0%b8%a5%e0%b9%87%e0%b8%81%e0%b8%a2%e0%b8%b1%e0%b8%81%e0%b8%a9%e0%b9%8c/

New report as result of closer /Europol cooperation from the joint annual workshop for Computer Emergency Response Teams in Europe
Today,  publishes its brief report on the annual  workshop for Computer Emergency Response Teams in Europe “CERTs in Europe”. This workshop has been organised every year since 2005.

The first part of this year's workshop focused on hands-on technical training for non- governmental CERTs in Europe.  In doing so,  strengthens CERTs capabilities in the EU Member States by sharing good operational practice and by facilitating suitable training and exercises.
Part II of the workshop, the /EC3 workshop, is a follow up event to last years's workshop with Europol. It has the same focus on cooperation between n/g CERTs in Europe and their national law enforcement counterparts. This year's topic was automated information sharing.
The public part of this meeting was summarised in the
8th  Workshop ‘CERTs in Europe’ report
Background:
In 2011,  started to collaborate with Europol and the first joint workshop was held in Prague the same year. The next years the annual  workshop was split in two parts, one part aimed only at n/g CERTs that had a more technical focus and one part aimed at both n/g CERTs and law enforcement representatives, organised together with Europol. The topic of the latter meetings was the cooperation in the fight against cybercrime. https://www.enisa.europa.eu/news/enisa-news/new-report-as-result-of-closer-enisa-europol-cooperation-from-the-joint-annual-workshop-for-computer-emergency-response-teams-in-europe

Dynamic Resolution: Domain Generation Algorithms is techniques, 

Adversaries may make use of Domain Generation Algorithms (DGAs) to dynamically identify a destination domain for command and control traffic rather than relying on a list of static IP addresses or domains. This has the advantage of making it much harder for defenders to block, track, or take over the command and control channel, as there potentially could be thousands of domains that malware can check for instructions.
DGAs can take the form of apparently random or "gibberish" strings (ex: istgmxdejdnxuyla.ru) when they construct domain names by generating each letter. Alternatively, some DGAs employ whole words as the unit by concatenating words together instead of letters (ex: cityjulydish.net). Many DGAs are time-based, generating a different domain for each time period (hourly, daily, monthly, etc). Others incorporate a seed value as well to make predicting future domains more difficult for defenders.
Adversaries may use DGAs for the purpose of 
. When contact is lost with the primary command and control server malware may employ a DGA as a means to reestablishing command and control.

European research and development priorities in cybersecurity
A new  report aims to identify the cybersecurity threats to European society and to identify priorities in research that will lead to mitigations before those cybersecurity threats materialise.

The proposed research priorities have the aim to make Europe ”a global leader in cybersecurity by 2025, in order to ensure the trust, confidence and protection of our citizens, consumers and enterprises online, and to enable a free and law-governed internet”, as stated at the Tallinn Digital Summit in September 2017.
Based on desktop research and interviews with experts, the report tries to foresee the European society in the near future, as far as 2025, and the societal changes brought by innovation in the digitally connected world.
The report recognises the interdependencies among the digital and physical world, the pervasiveness of connectivity in all aspects of society and industries, the evolution of the technologies and their effect on society.
The report focuses on identifying emerging challenges and on those current challenges that are evolving into significant risks to society. Closely related are the challenges in social dynamics, brought about by changes in society that technology has enabled.
For the full report:
Analysis of the European R&D priorities in cybersecurity https://www.enisa.europa.eu/news/enisa-news/european-research-and-development-priorities-in-cybersecurity

Keychain (or Keychain Services) is the macOS credential management system that stores account names, passwords, private keys, certificates, sensitive application data, payment data, and secure notes. Not Using a Random IV with CBC Mode # Description : 
The product generates and uses a predictable initialization Vector (IV) with Cipher Block Chaining (CBC) Mode, which causes algorithms to be susceptible to dictionary attacks when they are encrypted under the same key.

# Extend Description : 
Extended Description
CBC mode eliminates a weakness of Electronic Code Book (ECB) mode by allowing identical plaintext blocks to be encrypted to different ciphertext blocks. This is possible by the XOR-ing of an IV with the initial plaintext block so that every plaintext block in the chain is XOR'd with a different value before encryption. If IVs are reused, then identical plaintexts would be encrypted to identical ciphertexts. However, even if IVs are not identical but are predictable, then they still break the security of CBC mode against Chosen Plaintext Attacks (CPA).

# Migration : 
Potential Mitigations
Phase: Implementation
NIST recommends two methods of generating unpredictable IVs for CBC mode [
REF-1172
]. The first is to generate the IV randomly. The second method is to encrypt a nonce with the same key and cipher to be used to encrypt the plaintext. In this case the nonce must be unique but can be predictable, since the block cipher will act as a pseudo random permutation.

Improper Neutralization of Special Elements used in an LDAP Query ('LDAP Injection') # Description : 
The product constructs all or part of an LDAP query using externally-influenced input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special elements that could modify the intended LDAP query when it is sent to a downstream component.

# Extend Description : 


# Migration : 
Potential Mitigations
Phase: Implementation
Strategy: Input Validation
Assume all input is malicious. Use an "accept known good" input validation strategy, i.e., use a list of acceptable inputs that strictly conform to specifications. Reject any input that does not strictly conform to specifications, or transform it into something that does.
When performing input validation, consider all potentially relevant properties, including length, type of input, the full range of acceptable values, missing or extra inputs, syntax, consistency across related fields, and conformance to business rules. As an example of business rule logic, "boat" may be syntactically valid because it only contains alphanumeric characters, but it is not valid if the input is only expected to contain colors such as "red" or "blue."
Do not rely exclusively on looking for malicious or malformed inputs. This is likely to miss at least one undesirable input, especially if the code's environment changes. This can give attackers enough room to bypass the intended validation. However, denylists can be useful for detecting potential attacks or determining which inputs are so malformed that they should be rejected outright.
 https://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/90.html

Deciphering the landscape for Privacy by Design.  publishes its recommendations for policy makers, data protection authorities and experts
N/A

 publishes today, 12
th
January 2015, a cutting edge report on
Privacy and Data Protection by Design - from policy to engineering
. The report aims to bridge the gap between the legal framework and the available technological implementation measures. It provides an inventory of the existing approaches and privacy design strategies, and the technical building blocks of various degree of maturity from research and development. Limitations and inherent constraints are presented with recommendations for their mitigation.
The study, targeted at data protection authorities, policy makers, regulaltors, engineers and researchers, offers an insight into the technological aspect of the current state of the art. It presents the challenges and limitations of by-design principles for privacy and data protection, acts as a reference guide, and intends to improve the effectiveness of future policy in the area.
The main challenges identified in the report are two fold:
Existing policy doesn’t offer a guarantee for compliance with privacy by design. New policy should give incentives for adopting privacy by design.
New standards for electronic communication need to consider privacy and data protection, while privacy and data protection-ignorant standards should be out-phased.
Furthermore, privacy by design needs to be linked with the practice taking usability into account.
For the full report:
Privacy and Data Protection by Design - from policy to engineering
Background:
Privacy constitutes a core value of individuals and democratic societies. Decades of debate have gone into the manner of embedding these values and legal obligations into systems, preferably from the beginning of the design process. Barracuda warns of Zero-Day vulnerability in Email Security Gateway (ESG)
Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 280/66 (IT) Friday, May 26, 2023. Barracuda, a provider of email and network security solutions, has issued a warning to customers that a Zero-day vulnerability that can be compromised in Email Security Gateway (ESG) was discovered last week. The vulnerability led to unauthorized access to some Email Gateways devices. On May 19, 2023, Barracuda discovered the vulnerability in Email Security Gateway (ESG) numbered CVE-2023-2868, which could be compromised on some Email Security Gateway (ESG) devices. On May 20, 2023, all ESG devices worldwide were patched for the vulnerability.  Barracuda added that the vulnerability was located in the incoming email attachment screening module. As many organizations, including some prominent ones, use ESG devices, the problem could be widespread. Barracuda stated that this issue will not affect other products or SaaS email security services.  Affected organizations are advised to check their networks to detect systems compromised by attackers.

SonicWall warns of exploitable vulnerability in SonicOS.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 14/67 (IT) Friday, January 10, 2025. SonicWall has issued a warning urging customers to immediately upgrade their firewall's SonicOS firmware to protect against an authentication bypass vulnerability, CVE-2024-53704, with a CVSS score of 8.2.  This vulnerability exists in the SSL VPN and SSH management features. SonicWall states that users with these features enabled are at risk of attack.  To address and mitigate this vulnerability, SonicWall recommends upgrading to the following firmware versions: – Gen 6 / 6.5 hardware firewalls: SonicOS 6.5.5.1-6n or later – Gen 6 / 6.5 NSv firewalls: SonicOS 6.5.4.v-21s-RC2457 or later – Gen 7 firewalls: SonicOS 7.0.1-5165 or later, 7.1.3-7015 and above – TZ80: SonicOS 8.0.0-8037 or later.  In addition to the firmware upgrade, SonicWall also recommends the following mitigation steps: – Restrict SSL VPN access to trusted sources only, or disable access from the internet. – For SSH management, restrict access to trusted sources only, or disable SSH management from the internet.  SonicWall emphasizes that customers should take immediate action to mitigate the risk and prevent exploitation of this vulnerability.  Instructions on disabling SSL VPN access can be found at https://www.sonicwall.com/support/knowledge-base/how-can-i-setup-ssl-vpn/170505609285133.  https://www.thaicert.or.th/2025/01/10/sonicwall-%e0%b9%80%e0%b8%95%e0%b8%b7%e0%b8%ad%e0%b8%99%e0%b8%96%e0%b8%b6%e0%b8%87%e0%b8%8a%e0%b9%88%e0%b8%ad%e0%b8%87%e0%b9%82%e0%b8%ab%e0%b8%a7%e0%b9%88%e0%b9%83%e0%b8%99-sonicos-%e0%b8%aa%e0%b8%b2/

Kroes advocates for quick adoption of new Agency regulation proposal
European Commission Vice-President for the Digital Agenda, Neelie Kroes will encourage the EU's Council of Telecoms Ministers, meeting in Brussels on 3rd December, to rapidly adopt the Commission's regulation proposal of 30/09, to expand and modernise the Agency.

In a Memorandum released today 02/12, it was (among other things) announced that Commissioner and Vice-President Kroes
will encourage
the Council,
meeting on 3rd, Dec., starting at 15.00, in Brussels,
to reach a swift agreement on the draft Regulation to strengthen and modernise the , before the expiry of the current  mandate in March 2012.
The Council debate will be public (available on
http://video.consilium.europa.eu/
).
Background:
The Commission presented its regulation proposal to strengthen and modernise the Agency at the end of September 2010 (see
IP/10/1239
) to help EU Member States and private stakeholders develop their capabilities to prevent, detect and respond to cyber-security challenges.

Network Denial of Service: Direct Network Flood is techniques, 

Adversaries may attempt to cause a denial of service (DoS) by directly sending a high-volume of network traffic to a target. This DoS attack may also reduce the availability and functionality of the targeted system(s) and network. 
s are when one or more systems are used to send a high-volume of network packets towards the targeted service's network. Almost any network protocol may be used for flooding. Stateless protocols such as UDP or ICMP are commonly used but stateful protocols such as TCP can be used as well.
Botnets are commonly used to conduct network flooding attacks against networks and services. Large botnets can generate a significant amount of traffic from systems spread across the global Internet. Adversaries may have the resources to build out and control their own botnet infrastructure or may rent time on an existing botnet to conduct an attack. In some of the worst cases for distributed DoS (DDoS), so many systems are used to generate the flood that each one only needs to send out a small amount of traffic to produce enough volume to saturate the target network. In such circumstances, distinguishing DDoS traffic from legitimate clients becomes exceedingly difficult. Botnets have been used in some of the most high-profile DDoS flooding attacks, such as the 2012 series of incidents that targeted major US banks.

The ransomware group Dark Angels claims to have stolen data from chip manufacturer Nexperia.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 141/67 (IT) Thursday, April 18, 2024.  Chip manufacturer Nexperia confirmed it was targeted by hackers after a ransomware group claimed to have stolen a large amount of data from the company's systems.  Nexperia, based in the Netherlands, a subsidiary of China's Wingtech Technology, designs and manufactures semiconductors for the automotive, industrial, mobile, and consumer sectors. The ransomware group called Dark Angels (also known as Dunghill) announced on a Tor website on April 10th that it had stolen 1 TB of data from Nexperia.  The alleged data includes quality control information, customer folders of nearly 900 companies (including major companies such as Apple, IBM, Huawei, and SpaceX), confidential project data, industrial production information, and corporate data.  The ransomware group has publicly released some files as proof, but they threaten to leak all the stolen data unless a ransom is paid.  Nexperia has confirmed that some of its servers were accessed by unauthorized third parties in March and has notified data protection authorities and law enforcement.  The company cited an ongoing investigation as the reason for not being able to disclose further information. The Dark Angels ransomware group is known for its attack on Johnson Controls, where hackers claimed to have stolen 27 GB of data and demanded a $51 million ransom in February.  The company said the costs associated with the incident exceeded $27 million.  https://www.thaicert.or.th/2024/04/18/%e0%b8%81%e0%b8%a5%e0%b8%b8%e0%b9%88%e0%b8%a1%e0%b9%81%e0%b8%a3%e0%b8%99%e0%b8%8b%e0%b8%b1%e0%b8%a1%e0%b9%81%e0%b8%a7%e0%b8%a3%e0%b9%8c-dark-angels-%e0%b8%ad%e0%b9%89%e0%b8%b2%e0%b8%87%e0%b8%a7/

Warning! Scammers have a new trick to steal bank app access codes.

Warning! Scammers have a new trick to steal bank app access codes. The Thai Bankers' Association is warning the public about a new scam targeting people's money. This time, scammers impersonate various agencies and organizations by contacting people through LINE and using various deceptive tactics.  For example, they might pretend to be police officers, forcing victims to turn on their cameras for recording, claiming it's for evidence.  Or they might claim they will transfer money back to the victim and ask for personal information for verification.

Next, the scammers will trick the victim into a video call and then trick them into sharing their screen. They then instruct the victim to dial "131 followed by their bank app access code# and then press call," or some other number sequence that won't actually connect a call. This allows the scammer to see the code entered on the screen and use it to access the victim's banking app and steal their money.

The Thai Bankers' Association advises everyone to be vigilant and cautious, and not to fall for scammers who create situations to initiate video calls. Never give any personal information, including access codes, to anyone.  If you encounter online fraud, contact the AOC Center at 1441 for consultation, reporting, or assistance with online threats, 24 hours a day.

New chair of the Article 19 Expert Group on security of e-Trust services
 is happy to announce that Ulrich Latzenhofer from RTR Austria will be the new chair of the Article 19 Expert Group which focuses on security of electronic trust services in the EU.

Electronic trust services is what we call services like digital signatures, digital certificates, electronic seals, timestamps, etc. used in electronic transactions, to make them secure, trustworthy. The eIDAS regulation, which came into force in 2016, provides the EU wide legal framework for both trust services and national eID schemes. Article 19 of the eIDAS regulation sets the security requirements for trust service providers. The Article 19 Expert Group was set up by  in 2015, under the auspices of the Commission, to support voluntary collaboration between Member States about the technical details of how to implement Article 19. This is a voluntary non-binding process, between experts from ministries, agencies, supervisory bodies, national authorities, et cetera, who are involved with the implementation of Article 19. The group has experts from EU member states as well as EEA and EFTA countries. The Article 19 Expert Group meets twice a year.
At the last meeting in October in Malta, hosted by the Maltese Communications Authority, the group agreed to a new terms of reference for the group, formalizing a new modus operandi. At this meeting a new chair was elected, Ulrich Latzenhofer from the Austrian Regulatory Authority for Broadcasting and Telecommunications, will chair the group for the next 2 years.  will continue to support the group in the role of secretariat.
For further information about this work see:

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 352/66 (IT) Wednesday, July 19, 2023. Adobe issued a warning to customers about a critical remote code execution vulnerability in ColdFusion, tracked as CVE-2023-29300 (CVSS score: 9.8), which is being actively exploited.  Unauthenticated attackers can exploit this vulnerability to remotely execute commands on vulnerable Coldfusion 2018, 2021, and 2023 servers. Adobe has not disclosed technical details of the vulnerability but has addressed three vulnerabilities in ColdFusion:

1. CVE-2023-29298 (CVSS score: 7.5) Improper Access Control
2. CVE-2023-29300 (CVSS score: 9.8) Deserialization of Untrusted Data
3. CVE-2023-29301 (CVSS score: 5.9) Improper Restriction of Excessive Authentication Attempts

In March 2023, the US Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) added a critical Adobe ColdFusion vulnerability, tracked as CVE-2023-26360 (CVSS score: 8.6), to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities Catalog.  This Improper Access Control vulnerability could allow remote attackers to execute arbitrary code.

Prioritising eHealth cybersecurity against emerging challenges
This year, the European Union Agency for Cybersecurity () organises the 9th edition of the eHealth Security conference, in collaboration with the National Cybersecurity Centre of Hungary and Semmelweis University.

The full-day  event was hosted this year in Budapest and provided a unique opportunity for the stakeholder community to explore recent developments in the field, challenges and pathways forward.
The rising digitalisation and interconnectedness in healthcare has significantly increased the sector’s exposure to cyber threats and raised concerns regarding medical data being targeted by cybercrime. According to the 2024  Threat Landscape report, 487 incidents out of the total reported incidents analysed refer to the health sector, with 45% of them being ransomware attacks and 28% being data breaches.
Highlighted by the recent regulatory developments, such as the NIS2 transposition and the forthcoming European Health Data Space (EHDS), cybersecurity in the health sector and issues surrounding health data sharing have gained prominence. The subject was further emphasised in the political guidelines set for the European Commission 2024-2029, which commit the new Commission to developing a European action plan for the cybersecurity of hospitals and healthcare providers.
In this context, presentations, along with expert sessions reflecting on EU Member States national perspectives invited participants to further engage in discussions on the evolving health cybersecurity landscape and related challenges and opportunities. This exchange of valuable insights aimed to advance efforts to fortify the sector's public and private entities against cyber threats.

Cyber Europe 2012 – first results show success
’s initial findings from Europe’s biggest ever cyber security test show that the exercise was a success.

Cyber Europe 2012
was a day-long simulated cyber attack on Europe’s critical information infrastructures. It was used to analyse how participating countries’ and private sector organisations would cooperate in the event of a real large-scale attack.
’s headline observations from the “hot wash” exercise review session held today (05/10/2012) are:
There was frequent cooperation and information exchange between public and private sector organisations
Public-Private cooperation structure differed per country
Some countries responded by upscaling their national crisis cells/crisis plans/crisis structures
Some countries suffered from real incidents besides the CE2012 exercise
Familiarity with procedures is crucial for building a fast and effective response capability across Europe
There is a need for close understanding between players and a need to be able to communicate quickly with key contacts in national authorities and the private sector
The inclusion of private sector organisations as players was an excellent addition. Their input and experience helped build realistic scenarios and make exercise highly effective on the day. (Most Critical Information Infrastructure is owned by the private sector.)  Overall, there were approx. 60 banks and 60 ISPs taking part in the various countries.
Simulations were highly realistic. Players were under pressure so as to assess how this would affect cooperation
Conclusions from the exercise will be considered by the European Commission and Member States in drafting Europe’s Cyber Security Strategy
 plans to produce its Cyber Europe 2012 exercise report by the end of the year https://www.enisa.europa.eu/news/enisa-news/cyber-europe-2012-2013-first-results-show-success

Encrypted Channel: Asymmetric Cryptography is techniques, 

Adversaries may employ a known asymmetric encryption algorithm to conceal command and control traffic rather than relying on any inherent protections provided by a communication protocol. Asymmetric cryptography, also known as public key cryptography, uses a keypair per party: one public that can be freely distributed, and one private. Due to how the keys are generated, the sender encrypts data with the receiver’s public key and the receiver decrypts the data with their private key. This ensures that only the intended recipient can read the encrypted data. Common public key encryption algorithms include RSA and ElGamal.
For efficiency, many protocols (including SSL/TLS) use symmetric cryptography once a connection is established, but use asymmetric cryptography to establish or transmit a key. As such, these protocols are classified as 
.

Hide Artifacts: VBA Stomping is techniques, 

Adversaries may hide malicious Visual Basic for Applications (VBA) payloads embedded within MS Office documents by replacing the VBA source code with benign data.
MS Office documents with embedded VBA content store source code inside of module streams. Each module stream has a 
 that stores a separate compiled version of the VBA source code known as p-code. The p-code is executed when the MS Office version specified in the 
 stream (which contains the version-dependent description of the VBA project) matches the version of the host MS Office application.
An adversary may hide malicious VBA code by overwriting the VBA source code location with zero’s, benign code, or random bytes while leaving the previously compiled malicious p-code. Tools that scan for malicious VBA source code may be bypassed as the unwanted code is hidden in the compiled p-code. If the VBA source code is removed, some tools might even think that there are no macros present. If there is a version match between the 
 stream and host MS Office application, the p-code will be executed, otherwise the benign VBA source code will be decompressed and recompiled to p-code, thus removing malicious p-code and potentially bypassing dynamic analysis.

, which allows developers to use relative paths to specify an array of search paths used at runtime based on the location of the executable.  Additionally, if weak linking is used, such as the

Adversaries may interact with the native OS application programming interface (API) to execute behaviors. Native APIs provide a controlled means of calling low-level OS services within the kernel, such as those involving hardware/devices, memory, and processes.
 These native APIs are leveraged by the OS during system boot (when other system components are not yet initialized) as well as carrying out tasks and requests during routine operations.
Adversaries may abuse these OS API functions as a means of executing behaviors. Similar to 
, the native API and its hierarchy of interfaces provide mechanisms to interact with and utilize various components of a victimized system.
Native API functions (such as 
) may be directed invoked via system calls / syscalls, but these features are also often exposed to user-mode applications via interfaces and libraries.
 For example, functions such as the Windows API 
 or GNU 
 will allow programs and scripts to start other processes.
 This may allow API callers to execute a binary, run a CLI command, load modules, etc. as thousands of similar API functions exist for various system operations.
Higher level software frameworks, such as Microsoft .NET and macOS Cocoa, are also available to interact with native APIs. These frameworks typically provide language wrappers/abstractions to API functionalities and are designed for ease-of-use/portability of code.
Adversaries may use assembly to directly or in-directly invoke syscalls in an attempt to subvert defensive sensors and detection signatures such as user mode API-hooks.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT): Iranian government-backed hackers attempted to exploit unpatched Log4j systems to target Israeli entities. Microsoft stated that the threat group, known as MuddyWater (also known as Cobalt Ulster, Mercury, Seedworm, or Static Kitten), is linked to Iran's Ministry of Intelligence and Security (MOIS). The attack used a vulnerable SysAid Server instance, leveraging the Log4Shell vulnerability as the initial access vector. This deviates from their pattern of exploiting VMware applications in targeted attacks. The U.S. Department of Homeland Security's Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) considers the critical vulnerability in the open-source Java-based logging framework a persistent threat. Fortinet Fixes Critical RCE Vulnerability in FortiNAC, Update Urged.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 317/66 (IT) Monday, June 26, 2023. Fortinet has fixed a remote command execution vulnerability, CVE-2023-33299, affecting its FortiNAC solution.  FortiNAC is a Network Access Control (NAC) solution designed by Fortinet, used in various companies and organizations to secure and control network access by enforcing security policies, monitoring devices, and managing access rights. FortiNAC helps organizations protect their network infrastructure by providing visibility and control over devices connected to the network, such as laptops, smartphones, IoT devices, and other endpoints.  It allows network administrators to define and enforce security policies, authenticate and authorize devices, and monitor network activity. Fortinet has released security updates to address the critical vulnerability, CVE-2023-33299 (CVSS score 9.6/10), which could allow unauthenticated attackers to execute arbitrary code and commands on vulnerable devices. The company urges customers to update immediately. Affected products include: FortiNAC versions 9.4.0 through 9.4.2, FortiNAC versions 9.2.0 through 9.2.7, FortiNAC versions 9.1.0 through 9.1.9, FortiNAC versions 7.2.0 through 7.2.1, all versions of FortiNAC 8.8, all versions of FortiNAC 8.7, all versions of FortiNAC 8.6, all versions of FortiNAC 8.5, and all versions of FortiNAC 8.3.  https://www.thaicert.or.th/2023/06/26/fortinet-%e0%b9%81%e0%b8%81%e0%b9%89%e0%b9%84%e0%b8%82%e0%b8%8a%e0%b9%88%e0%b8%ad%e0%b8%87%e0%b9%82%e0%b8%ab%e0%b8%a7%e0%b9%88%e0%b8%97%e0%b8%b5%e0%b9%88%e0%b8%aa%e0%b8%b3%e0%b8%84%e0%b8%b1%e0%b8%8d/

CISA adds Android Pixel and Sunhillo SureLine vulnerabilities to the Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 94/67 (IT) Friday, March 8, 2024.  The US Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) has added two vulnerabilities affecting Android Pixel and Sunhillo SureLine to the Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog: – CVE-2023-21237:  An information disclosure vulnerability in Android Pixel. – CVE-2021-36380: An OS Command Injection vulnerability in Sunhillo SureLine. The Android Pixel vulnerability, CVE-2023-21237, allows for information disclosure without requiring privileges or user interaction.  Google addressed this issue in June 2023. The second vulnerability, CVE-2021-36380, is an OS Command Injection vulnerability in Sunhillo SureLine.  Exploiting this vulnerability allows execution of arbitrary commands with root privileges. According to Binding Operational Directive (BOD) 22-01: Reducing the Significant Risk of Known Exploited Vulnerabilities, FCEB agencies must remediate these vulnerabilities by the specified deadline to prevent attacks. Experts recommend that private organizations also review the catalog and address these vulnerabilities in their infrastructure.  CISA has ordered federal civilian agencies to remediate these vulnerabilities by March 26, 2024.  https://www.thaicert.or.th/2024/03/08/cisa-%e0%b9%80%e0%b8%9e%e0%b8%b4%e0%b9%88%e0%b8%a1%e0%b8%8a%e0%b9%88%e0%b8%ad%e0%b8%87%e0%b9%82%e0%b8%ab%e0%b8%a7%e0%b9%88-android-pixel-%e0%b9%81%e0%b8%a5%e0%b8%b0-sunhillo-sureline-%e0%b8%a5/

Microsoft Patch Tuesday for March 2024 addressed 59 vulnerabilities.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 102/67 (IT) Thursday, March 14, 2024, Microsoft released the March 2023 Patch Tuesday update that addressed 59 vulnerabilities in its products. Two vulnerabilities, CVE-2024-21407 and CVE-2024-21408, are rated Critical, and the remaining 57 are rated Important.

- CVE-2024-21407 is a Remote Code Execution vulnerability in Windows Hyper-V.
- CVE-2024-21408 is a Denial of Service vulnerability in Windows Hyper-V.

The most severe vulnerability addressed by Microsoft is an Open Management Infrastructure (OMI) Remote Code Execution vulnerability, CVE-2024-21334 (CVSS 9.8). An unauthenticated attacker could execute code on OMI instances accessible over the internet. Currently, none of the vulnerabilities addressed in the March 2023 Microsoft Patch Tuesday security update have been exploited in attacks.

Remote Services: Distributed Component Object Model is techniques, 

Adversaries may use 
 to interact with remote machines by taking advantage of Distributed Component Object Model (DCOM). The adversary may then perform actions as the logged-on user.
The Windows Component Object Model (COM) is a component of the native Windows application programming interface (API) that enables interaction between software objects, or executable code that implements one or more interfaces. Through COM, a client object can call methods of server objects, which are typically Dynamic Link Libraries (DLL) or executables (EXE). Distributed COM (DCOM) is transparent middleware that extends the functionality of COM beyond a local computer using remote procedure call (RPC) technology.
Permissions to interact with local and remote server COM objects are specified by access control lists (ACL) in the Registry.
 By default, only Administrators may remotely activate and launch COM objects through DCOM.
Through DCOM, adversaries operating in the context of an appropriately privileged user can remotely obtain arbitrary and even direct shellcode execution through Office applications
 as well as other Windows objects that contain insecure methods.
 DCOM can also execute macros in existing documents
 and may also invoke 
 (DDE) execution directly through a COM created instance of a Microsoft Office application
, bypassing the need for a malicious document. DCOM can be used as a method of remotely interacting with 
.

Hide Artifacts: Hidden File System is techniques, 

Adversaries may use a hidden file system to conceal malicious activity from users and security tools. File systems provide a structure to store and access data from physical storage. Typically, a user engages with a file system through applications that allow them to access files and directories, which are an abstraction from their physical location (ex: disk sector). Standard file systems include FAT, NTFS, ext4, and APFS. File systems can also contain other structures, such as the Volume Boot Record (VBR) and Master File Table (MFT) in NTFS.
Adversaries may use their own abstracted file system, separate from the standard file system present on the infected system. In doing so, adversaries can hide the presence of malicious components and file input/output from security tools. Hidden file systems, sometimes referred to as virtual file systems, can be implemented in numerous ways. One implementation would be to store a file system in reserved disk space unused by disk structures or standard file system partitions.
 Another implementation could be for an adversary to drop their own portable partition image as a file on top of the standard file system.
 Adversaries may also fragment files across the existing file system structure in non-standard ways.
 https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1564/005/

A new hacker group, "GambleForce," is using SQL injection attacks to target organizations in the APAC region.  The Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 531/66 (IT), Friday, December 15, 2023, and Group-IB have discovered this previously unknown hacker group.  They have been linked to SQL injection attacks against companies in the Asia-Pacific (APAC) region, stealing sensitive data such as user credentials.  These operations have been ongoing since at least September 2023. They have also exploited CVE-2023-23752, a medium-severity vulnerability in the Joomla CMS.  The group has targeted 24 organizations across various sectors, including government, retail, and tourism, in countries such as Australia, Brazil, China, India, Indonesia, the Philippines, South Korea, and Thailand, with six successful attacks. GambleForce's modus operandi involves using specific open-source tools such as dirsearch, sqlmap, Tinyproxy, and redis-rogue-getshell in various stages of the attack, with the ultimate goal of exfiltrating sensitive data from compromised networks. Alert - Detection Report of the BangkokShell Campaign Specifically Targeting Organizations in Thailand

The TTC-CERT has examined several suspicious files received from a Thai security agency and found that all files are part of a cyberattack specifically targeting Thailand. The attack utilizes sophisticated malware to achieve cyber espionage objectives. The TTC-CERT has named this campaign BangkokShell.

Overall, the BangkokShell campaign leverages open-source projects to develop attack tools and employs various anti-detection measures such as Dynamic API Resolution, Indirect Calls, stackstrings, and multiple encryption types. The BangkokShell attack process begins with DLL Side-loading to load obfuscated shellcode into the process memory before deobfuscating it. It then uses Reflective Code Loading to load and execute the payload, a Remote Access Trojan (RAT), without leaving any traces on the filesystem.  TTC-CERT refers to this payload as RahadRAT. Analysis reveals interesting self-protection mechanisms, including password authentication support and the use of the CRC-16/XMODEM algorithm to verify data exchanged between the malware and the Command and Control (C2) server.  It supports 14 C2 commands designed to control and collect data from the target computer before obfuscating it with the RC4 (Rivest Cipher 4) algorithm and sending it to the C2.

Insecure Design A new category for 2021 focuses on risks related to design and architectural flaws, with a call for more use of threat modeling, secure design patterns, and reference architectures. As a community we need to move beyond  "shift-left" in the coding space to pre-code activities that are critical for the principles of Secure by Design. Notable Common Weakness Enumerations (CWEs) include  CWE-209: Generation of Error Message Containing Sensitive Information ,  CWE-256: Unprotected Storage of Credentials ,  CWE-501: Trust Boundary Violation , and  CWE-522: Insufficiently Protected Credentials .
Insecure design is a broad category representing different weaknesses, expressed as “missing or ineffective control design.” Insecure design is not the source for all other Top 10 risk categories. There is a difference between insecure design and insecure implementation. We differentiate between design flaws and implementation defects for a reason, they have different root causes and remediation. A secure design can still have implementation defects leading to vulnerabilities that may be exploited. An insecure design cannot be fixed by a perfect implementation as by definition, needed security controls were never created to defend against specific attacks. One of the factors that contribute to insecure design is the lack of business risk profiling inherent in the software or system being developed, and thus the failure to determine what level of security design is required. https://owasp.org/Top10/A04_2021-Insecure_Design/

Proxy is techniques, 

Adversaries may use a connection proxy to direct network traffic between systems or act as an intermediary for network communications to a command and control server to avoid direct connections to their infrastructure. Many tools exist that enable traffic redirection through proxies or port redirection, including 
, ZXProxy, and ZXPortMap. 
 Adversaries use these types of proxies to manage command and control communications, reduce the number of simultaneous outbound network connections, provide resiliency in the face of connection loss, or to ride over existing trusted communications paths between victims to avoid suspicion. Adversaries may chain together multiple proxies to further disguise the source of malicious traffic.
Adversaries can also take advantage of routing schemes in Content Delivery Networks (CDNs) to proxy command and control traffic.

European Cyber Security Month - building together a joint EU advocacy campaign!
The first Coordinators' Meeting for the European Cyber Security Month (ECSM) 2013 will take place on Monday 27th of May at 's premises in Athens. The meeting will focus on getting to know this year's participants and sharing best practices from experience to date.

European Cyber Security Month is an EU advocacy campaign that takes place in October. ECSM aims to promote cyber security awareness among citizens. The campaign has the objective of  modifying perceptions of cyber threats in everyday life - at work, or when online privately.  It also aims to provide updated security information through education, good practices and competitions. ECSM’13 activities will take place throughout the month of October all over Europe, with the support of the European Commission and .

Unprotected Storage of Credentials # Description : 
Storing a password in plaintext may result in a system compromise.

# Extend Description : 
Extended Description
Password management issues occur when a password is stored in plaintext in an application's properties, configuration file, or memory. Storing a plaintext password in a configuration file allows anyone who can read the file access to the password-protected resource. In some contexts, even storage of a plaintext password in memory is considered a security risk if the password is not cleared immediately after it is used.

# Migration : 
Potential Mitigations
Phase: Architecture and Design
Avoid storing passwords in easily accessible locations.
Phase: Architecture and Design
Consider storing cryptographic hashes of passwords as an alternative to storing in plaintext.
A programmer might attempt to remedy the password management problem by obscuring the password with an encoding function, such as base 64 encoding, but this effort does not adequately protect the password because the encoding can be detected and decoded easily.
Effectiveness: None

Synlab Italia, a medical center company, suspends operations after a ransomware attack.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 148/67 (IT) Wednesday, April 24, 2024. Last week, on April 18, Synlab Italia, a medical center company, announced that it had suffered a security breach and had to shut down all computers to limit the damage. Synlab Italia is part of Synlab, which operates in 30 countries worldwide, with 380 laboratories and medical centers across Italy, with an annual turnover of $426 million.  As a result of this incident, all laboratory analysis and sample collection services have been suspended until further notice. Customers are advised to contact Synlab by phone, as email services have also been suspended.  The company recently announced that it has begun gradually reactivating some services, with no definite recovery timeline specified. The company advises customers to check its website or follow Synlab's social media channels for further updates. Ivanti disclosed that a critical vulnerability in Cloud Service Appliance (CSA), designated CVE-2024-8190, is being actively exploited.  This vulnerability has a CVSS score of 7.2 and allows for remote code execution, but attackers require administrator privileges to exploit it.  CVE-2024-8190 affects Ivanti CSA versions 4.6 Patch 518 and earlier, which are now end-of-life.  It was addressed in Patch 519 and customers are advised to upgrade to CSA version 5.0 for continued support and security. Last Friday, Ivanti confirmed exploitation of this vulnerability in a limited number of customers. While details about the attackers remain undisclosed, the U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) has added this flaw to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog and mandated federal agencies to patch it by October 4, 2024. Improper Neutralization of HTTP Headers for Scripting Syntax # Description : 
The product does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes web scripting syntax in HTTP headers that can be used by web browser components that can process raw headers, such as Flash.

# Extend Description : 
Extended Description
An attacker may be able to conduct cross-site scripting and other attacks against users who have these components enabled.
If a product does not neutralize user controlled data being placed in the header of an HTTP response coming from the server, the header may contain a script that will get executed in the client's browser context, potentially resulting in a cross site scripting vulnerability or possibly an HTTP response splitting attack. It is important to carefully control data that is being placed both in HTTP response header and in the HTTP response body to ensure that no scripting syntax is present, taking various encodings into account.

# Migration : 
Potential Mitigations
Phase: Architecture and Design
Perform output validation in order to filter/escape/encode unsafe data that is being passed from the server in an HTTP response header.
Phase: Architecture and Design
Disable script execution functionality in the clients' browser.
 https://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/644.html

CISA says Critical Zyxel NAS vulnerability exploited in attacks.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 320/66 (IT) Tuesday, June 27, 2023. The US Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) warns of a recently patched critical vulnerability affecting network-attached storage (NAS) products manufactured by Zyxel, which has issued an advisory for the NAS326, NAS540, and NAS542 devices. Specifically, devices running firmware version 5.21 and earlier are affected by the critical flaw. Tracked as CVE-2023-27992, the vulnerability can be exploited for unauthenticated arbitrary command injection. The flaw resides in the pre-authentication command injection of the devices. Some Zyxel NAS devices may allow unauthenticated attackers to execute some operating system (OS) commands remotely by sending crafted HTTP requests. Zyxel has released patches for affected products and urged customers to install them as soon as possible. CISA added the vulnerability to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities Catalog on Friday, June 23, informing users that CVE-2023-27992 is actively exploited in attacks. CISA has ordered federal agencies to take action by July 14.  https://www.thaicert.or.th/2023/06/27/cisa-%e0%b8%81%e0%b8%a5%e0%b9%88%e0%b8%b2%e0%b8%a7%e0%b8%96%e0%b8%b6%e0%b8%87%e0%b8%8a%e0%b9%88%e0%b8%ad%e0%b8%87%e0%b9%82%e0%b8%ab%e0%b8%a7%e0%b9%88%e0%b8%a3%e0%b8%b0%e0%b8%94%e0%b8%b1%e0%b8%9a-criti/
